title: In Westchester, 2 Moderates Battle for Top County Post
sentence: In the race for Westchester County executive, voters will choose between two moderate candidates who diverge dramatically in their assessment of Westchester and their approach to government.

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime
sentence: In " The Puppetmaster of Lodz, " Mr. Segal ' s character is a Jewish man who has escaped from one of the most notorious concentration camps.

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime
sentence: He is hiding in a small rooming house on the outskirts of Berlin, and he refuses to believe that the war has been over for five years.

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime

sentence: She keeps urging him to come out, but he is convinced he will be arrested and killed if he does.

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime
sentence: Most of all, if the Nazis have been defeated, he has to learn to live again.

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime
sentence: It is the struggle to remember what being alive means, when one ' s memory served death, destruction and betrayal, that forms the basis of the play.

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime

title: The Indelible Memories Of a Ghetto in Wartime

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: Stung by complaints that it is moving too slowly against global warming, the Clinton Administration has devised a set of rewards for companies that cut emissions of heat-trapping gases faster than the Government would require under a pending international treaty.

sentence: The Administration ' s new approach has several elements, which include these:

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: *Energy producers and consumers that reduce emissions quickly would get credits, so that those moving fastest would benefit the most when, as the Administration envisions, the Government issues pollution permits that companies can buy and sell.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: This trading of pollution permits is the Administration ' s favored approach for letting the marketplace choose how to reduce emissions.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: That would help to encourage companies to comply earlier.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: *Tax incentives and subsidies, requiring Congressional approval, would also prompt companies to move more quickly.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: The new approach would not substantially change the Administration ' s basic goal: to require in the new treaty that industrial nations emit no more of the gases in 2010 than they did in 1990.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: The Administration is expected to propose at the talks in Bonn that industrial nations meet that target, as an average, during a multiyear period falling around 2010, probably during the period from 2008 to 2012.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: The Administration will also suggest that deeper reductions occur in later periods, perhaps a 5 percent cut below 1990 ' s levels as 2020 approaches.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: The initial reductions would be modest, but they would come soon.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
sentence: This package would be in addition to the plan for pollution permit credits.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: WHAT must a corporation in the midst of secret discussions with other companies about a contemplated merger or acquisition tell the public?

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: The Supreme Court recently agreed to hear a case that poses the question, in a contest between the executives of a company who did not disclose talks, and shareholders who claim the officers committed fraud.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: The case squarely pits the stockholders ' interests to know of important company developments against the needs of officers to keep negotiations confidential in order to facilitate deal making.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: Appeals courts in two Federal circuits have already issued rulings that conflict with each other about the kinds of disclosures required under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure

sentence: " On the one hand, the timing of disclosure of ongoing merger negotiations is a matter of great sensitivity, since premature disclosure may affect or scuttle the negotiations, " said a brief by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: On the other hand, shareholders have a right not to be misled about ongoing negotiations that are material to their investment decisions. "

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: The case under review, Basic Inc. v. Levinson, involves the confidential talks leading up to the merger of two chemical companies, Basic Inc. and Combustion Engineering Inc.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: A day later, the president of Basic told The Cleveland Plain Dealer that the company knew no reason for the stock ' s activity and that no negotiations were under way with any company for a merger.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: A Federal appeals court said that company officers had a duty to disclose the talks once it decided to comment at all.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure
sentence: The court relied heavily for its ruling on a famous decision two decades ago in a case involving fraud committed by officials of Texas Gulf Sulphur who were found to have misled the public by denying reports that the company had found valuable ore in Timmins, Ontario.

title: Business and the Law; Merger Talks and Disclosure

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: The long-running patent dispute between eBay and MercExchange entered a new and, quite likely, still not final phase on Monday when the Supreme Court sent the case back to the lower federal courts.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: The justices told the lower courts to reconsider whether eBay -- having been found by a jury to have infringed two MercExchange patents on the method behind the " Buy It Now " feature of its online auction business -- should be barred from continuing to use the method.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: The decision left the resolution of this dispute uncertain, given the court ' s insistence that judges must engage in a case-by-case examination of requests for patent injunctions rather than apply one-size-fits-all rules.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: In a unanimous opinion by Justice Clarence Thomas, the court said that neither of the lower courts that handled MercExchange ' s request for an injunction had approached it correctly, despite having reached opposite conclusions.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: The Federal District Court in Norfolk, Va., denied MercExchange ' s request for an injunction on the ground that MercExchange had not itself engaged in " commercial activity " to market its patents.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: MercExchange, a small company in Great Falls, Va., tried but failed in the late 1990 ' s to raise the capital necessary to market its invention.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: After failing to reach agreement with eBay on a license fee, MercExchange filed suit in 2001.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: It won damages of $25 million but wanted an injunction as well.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: The denial of the injunction was wrong, Justice Thomas said, because the court took too categorical an approach in relying on MercExchange ' s failure to put its patents to practical use.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: " Some patent holders, such as university researchers or self-made inventors, might reasonably prefer to license their patents, rather than undertake efforts to secure the financing necessary to bring their works to market themselves, " Justice Thomas said.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: But, he continued, the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, a specialized court here that handles patent appeals, was also in error for the analysis it applied when it overturned the district court ' s denial of the injunction.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: The appeals court invoked what it called the " general rule " that " a permanent injunction will issue once infringement and validity have been adjudged. "

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: Justice Thomas said that in resorting to the general rule, " just as the district court erred in its categorical denial of injunctive relief, the court of appeals erred in its categorical grant of such relief. "

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case
sentence: In patent cases no less than in other kinds of cases, he said, the party seeking an injunction must meet a four-factor test.

title: Justices Order Rethinking Of eBay Case

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: A BATTLE continues in suburbia: it is deer vs. gardeners.

sentence: Those who deal with this problem every day are gradually learning there is no sure way to win.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Yet, there is always hope.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Every kind of spray, remedy, planting trick or fencing is tried, yet nothing seems to be a real answer.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: It could be that residents themselves are the worst enemy.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: As suburbia has spread and built up, the deer herds have not had to scurry for food.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Rather they find delicious meals without much effort in well-landscaped backyards.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: There are plenty of nesting sites to raise young and natural predators that have long since gone elsewhere to live.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: In the suburbs, hunting is not a factor.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Depending on the source, most observers believe that a deer can eat five to eight pounds of food a day.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: And in the spring, when the does are lactating, the demand for succulent greenery is even greater.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: But research has confirmed that there are certain sorts of plants that deer choose not to eat.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Plants with heavy scents are not to a deer ' s liking.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Any plant with fuzzy or prickly leaves is usually left alone, although there have been reports of deer eating roses.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: But if a stem exudes a milky sap, the deer seem to be scared off.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: This fact explains why euphorbias, milkweed and butterflyweed are left alone.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Gardeners have given up on some particular plants because they find they plant them merely for the deer, not themselves.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Among these are tulips, day lilies, hostas and yew.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Even some of the spectacular rhododendron species and azaleas are not immune from attack by hungry deer.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Of course all sorts of repellants have been developed.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Most of them are based on the knowledge that if the plants do not smell good, the deer will leave them alone.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: One of the early sprays used was Thiram, which proved effective for a time.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: There are many others on the market such as Deer Off, Deer Away and Bobbex.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Yet the deer are never completely fooled and in a few weeks, become quite brave and feed on.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Some gardeners have even resorted to mixing their own sprays with eggs, garlic and liquid soap.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: One of the latest research endeavors is using compounds found in daffodils.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Since it is well known that deer will leave daffodils alone, the researchers have made an effort to extract, in some tangible form, the compound found in these flowers.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Another form of scent control is bottling the urine of known deer predators.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: The green industry has been making available bottled urine of foxes, wolves and coyotes in an effort to protect large nurseries.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: The products have worked for a time, but as with all repellants repeat applications are necessary.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: And in time, the deer become wise to this ruse.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Several noise makers have been used as well.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Sometimes homeowners have set up noise-making devices to scare away the deer.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: One suburbanite even played a radio to a loud rock music station until neighbors complained.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Another keeps bright lights burning all night.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: If those noises don ' t scare off the deer, many get a large dog with a ferocious bark.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: The ultimate protection, of course, is a high fence, at least eight feet tall.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: It should also be secure at the base, too, as the deer can not only jump but crawl under as well.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: In many situations, especially for larger properties, these fences are often electrified, but this sometimes causes more problems for the homeowner.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Also, there may be local ordinances about electrification.

sentence: There are as many answers to this question as there are gardeners.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Yet there are a few plants that deer do seem to avoid.

sentence: And with some trepidation, here are a few suggestions.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Since flowers are always a delight to have around, some of the showiest blooms that do seem to survive are the stately columbines, the many kinds of perennial geraniums and old-fashioned bleeding hearts.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: There seems to be something about the formidable size of baptisia that deters the deer herds.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: The rather elegant blue flowers survive nicely.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: The tall spikes of bugbanes survive well, too, as do those stately spikes of gay feather.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Ferns seem to be safe from nibblers as well as epimediums with their heart-shaped leaves.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Heaths and heathers thrive nicely and entire spread of the sturdy plants can fill grand expanses.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Some of the shrubs that do well include inkberry, leucothoe and most of the spruces.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Forsythia seems to be safe from harm as well as the boxwoods.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Some of the daphnes have been able to thrive as well as certain hydrangeas.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Recommendations are chancy at best, for what works well in one area, does not succeed in another.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: Experience is always the best teacher.

title: Keeping Hungry Deer From Tasty Backyards
sentence: The important thing is to keep trying, and not give up.

sentence: The first document generally recognized as written in the French language - the agreement between two grandsons of Charlemagne to avoid conflict over the " middle kingdom " between France and Germany - dates to the middle of the ninth century.

sentence: One interesting aspect of this document is that it concerns the territory later known as Alsace and Lorraine, thus prefiguring the very territorial issue that gnawed at French-German relations for much of the next thousand years until its latest resolution after World War II.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: The Strasbourg Oaths, as the agreement is known, thus appropriately stands at the beginning point of a great literature, a literature central to the self-conception and cultural pride of the French.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: This remarkable collection of brief essays on topics ranging from the Strasbourg Oaths of 842 to a 1983 broadcast of " Apostrophes, " France ' s celebrated televised literary interview program, is far more than a survey of 12 centuries of writing in France.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: It is a fascinating, generally very readable and almost always unpredictable ramble through the thick and varied garden of culture tended for these many centuries by the French people.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: The volume ' s editor, Denis Hollier, a professor of French at Yale University, has managed the considerable feat of compiling hundreds of brief essays by 164 mostly American scholars of French literature and to impose on the whole an extraordinary unity.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: The result is a Francophile ' s delight and a lucid, often entertaining display of erudition.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: In his introduction, Professor Hollier avers that this new history " has been written from both sides of as many borders as possible.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: " Citing Chateaubriand to the effect that it is hilarious to find out who France ' s great writers are in London and Berlin, Mr. Hollier notes how unusual it is for an ambitious history of French literature to have been written outside of France, and in English no less.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: That is already one of the borders crossed in this undertaking.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: But Mr. Hollier also means that literary history has itself become a far more complex and delicate enterprise than it ever was before.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: The definition of literature has been expanded to mean something vaster than the mere study of individual works and individual authors.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: The modern critics, many of them French, have produced new theories of meaning, of indeterminacy, of the separation of a text from its author.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: And so, in this volume, Mr. Hollier largely avoids the conventional form of literary history that unfolds as a continuous narrative of events and personalities.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: This is history that leaps from jewel to jewel in the great French crown; it is a discontinuous handling of various topics that,in itself suggests the richness of its immense subject.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French
sentence: Each of these many dozens of essays, few more than seven or eight pages long, begins with a date and a kind of newspaper headline, such as " 842: Louis the German and Charles the Bald, Grandsons of Charlemagne, Ratify the Serments de Strasbourg.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

sentence: The episodic guiding principle used in these volumes may frustrate those looking for complete essays on specific authors.

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: Books of The Times; A Hefty Ramble Through 12 Centuries of French

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Q: Many neuroscientists think of the brain as a great calculating machine.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: By contrast, you study emotion and feeling.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: What led you in that direction?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: I got interested in the emotions after studying patients who had lost the ability to emote and feel under certain circumstances.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Many of those patients also had major impairments in their ability to make decisions.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: The possible link between emotion and decision making was so striking that it forced me to look into the emotions.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Here ' s an example: Some patients lose a part of the brain called the amygdala.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: As a result, they cannot recognize fear in people ' s expressions, and they cannot experience fear themselves.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: What is the distinction, as you define it, between emotion and feeling?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: When we talk about emotion, we really talk about a collection of behaviors that are produced by the brain.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: You can look at a person in the throes of an emotion and observe changes in the face, in the body posture, in the coloration of the skin and so on.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Feeling, however, is a private process, an inner process.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: It involves your perception of all the changes that are taking place in your body during an emotion.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Can you give me a specific example?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Say, sadness?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: When you experience the emotion of sadness, there will be changes in facial expression, and your body will be closed in, withdrawn.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: There are also changes in your heart, your guts: they slow down.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: And there are hormonal changes.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: The feeling of sadness involves your perception of these changes in your body.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: You may have the sense that your body has slowed down, has less energy, feels ill.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Your thought processes also change.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: The production of new images slows down, your attention may be concentrated on a few images.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: By contrast, when you experience joy and elation, you become able to create images more rapidly, and your attention can be proportionally shorter.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: You feel quick, not stuck.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Emotions and feelings can be slippery.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Is there, nonetheless, a basic human repertory?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Absolutely.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: When you do studies across cultures you find an enormous stability.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: You find certain repertories of behaviors that obviously have been placed in our biology during the history of evolution because they match certain challenges in the environment.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: When we want judges or generals or politicians to make good decisions, we often ask them to think dispassionately.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: But you have said that our ability to reason is as likely to be harmed by a lack of emotion as by an excess of emotion.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: How is this so?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Rather than being a luxury, emotions are a very intelligent way of driving an organism toward certain outcomes.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Let ' s say you are trying to make a complicated decision.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: If you try to do a cost-benefit analysis, it may take you forever to decide whether to do A or B.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: However, if you have previously been in similar situations, and if you have been either rewarded or punished by the choices you made in those situations, then emotional memory may help you with your current choice.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: That help may come in the form of a gut feeling or, more subtly, in the form of a nonconscious bias that leads you in a certain direction.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: And we know this because if you ' re deprived of those emotions then, lo and behold, rather than being sort of a coolheaded reasoner, you become a rather poor reasoner.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: But using emotional memory to guide decisions doesn ' t always work.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Exactly.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: If you have not had the right experiences, or if you have not classified your experiences in a good way, your emotional memory could be leading you in the wrong direction.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: So I am not saying that you should start listening to your emotions and do what your emotions tell you.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: This is not a " touchy feely " prescription.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: So if the lesson for laypeople is not to " get in touch " with their emotions, what is it?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Don ' t denigrate the fact that emotions can play a role in how you normally operate.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: One can fall into the trap of being hyperrationalistic -- emotional memory can have a very good tempering effect.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: And don ' t interpret reason as separate from emotion, but as part of a continuum.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Both reason and emotion are part of our life mechanisms.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Has this fact made you more likely to trust your gut when reading complex data?

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like
sentence: Oh, no, to the contrary.

title: The Way We Live Now: 5-7-00: Questions for: Antonio Damasio; What Feelings Feel Like

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: In an important milestone toward making powerful computers that exploit the mind-bending possibilities of calculating with individual atoms, scientists at the I.B.M. Almaden Research Center, in San Jose, Calif., are announcing today that they have performed the most complex such calculation yet: factoring the number 15.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: The answer itself was no surprise: 3 and 5, the numbers that divide into 15, leaving no remainder.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: But the exercise that led to that simple result -- the first factoring of a number with an exotic device called a quantum computer -- holds the promise of one day solving problems now considered impossible, and cracking seemingly impenetrable codes.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Tiny though they are, the switches that manipulate ones and zeroes in current state-of-the-art computers each consist of billions of atoms.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: In the quantum computing experiment, the scientists performed the calculation by manipulating single atoms, the submicroscopic equivalent of abacus beads.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: This confirmed a big advantage: because of the chimerical nature of quantum mechanics, the law that rules the atomic realm, the procedure ' s multiple steps could be carried out simultaneously.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: If this kind of quantum parallelism can be extended to a larger scale, an effort far from trivial, numbers hundreds of digits long could be factored with ease.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Since many schemes used to protect electronic information are based on the near impossibility of factoring large numbers, building a working quantum computer would be not only a mathematical coup but a cryptographic one as well, potentially putting much of the world ' s most secret information in jeopardy.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: " We now believe that quantum computing is going to be a fact of nature, " said Dr. Isaac L. Chuang, who led the team of researchers, from I.B.M. and Stanford University.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: " That ' s incredibly surprising to me.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: I started out thinking that quantum computing was not going to be a viable enterprise. "

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: He said he was happy to have been proved wrong.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Dr. Peter Shor, the scientist at AT&T Laboratories who proved seven years ago that quantum factoring was a theoretical possibility, called the new advance, being reported today in the journal Nature, " an impressive accomplishment, " though he added, " There ' s still a long road ahead before we develop useful quantum computers. "

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Factoring is what mathematicians call an intractable problem.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: It is easy to factor small numbers, but as they increase in size, calculation time grows exponentially.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: In 1999, experts set a record by factoring a 155-digit number -- a feat that required 292 computers grinding away for half a year.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Because of the exponential nature of the problem, factoring a number twice that long could take hundreds of millions of years.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Cryptographers have drawn on this fact to develop codes considered all but unbreakable.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: The sender of a message picks two long prime numbers (those that have no factors) and multiplies them together.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: This yields a larger number that becomes the key used to encrypt the text.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Breaking the code entails working backward to recover the original factors, a procedure requiring enough calculations to flummox a supercomputer.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Quantum computing, however, works by different rules.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: In 1994, Dr. Shor invented an algorithm -- a sequence of operations -- that would allow a quantum computer to do the calculations simultaneously, factoring numbers hundreds of digits long in perhaps minutes.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: This is possible because a quantum computer ' s counters consist of single atoms, which can point up or down, indicating 1 or 0, the two symbols of binary arithmetic.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: More important, quantum mechanics allows an atom to point both up and down simultaneously, indicating 1 and 0 at the same time.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Thus two atoms can simultaneously register four quantities: 00, 01, 10 and 11 (the numbers 0 through 3 in the binary tongue).

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Three atoms can hold eight numbers, four can hold 16.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: By the time you reach seven atoms -- the number harnessed for the I.B.M. experiment -- you have a tiny device with the capability of simultaneously registering 128 different numbers.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Flipping the atoms up and down in various patterns causes a calculation to be performed -- on all the numbers at once.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: In the experiment, Dr. Chuang and his colleagues -- Dr. Lieven M. K. Vandersypen, Matthias Steffen, Gregory Breyta, Dr. Costantino S. Yannoni and Dr. Mark H. Sherwood -- used a molecule consisting primarily of fluorine and carbon atoms.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: A vial of liquid containing quadrillions of the molecules was placed inside a machine called a nuclear magnetic resonance spectrometer, using the same technology on which hospitals draw for M.R.I. scanning.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: By bombarding the molecules with a precise sequence of electromagnetic pulses, the experimenters carefully flipped the atoms back and forth between 1 and 0, carrying out the steps of Dr. Shor ' s algorithm.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: Rapidly factoring numbers the size of those used in cryptography would probably require delicate manipulation of tens of thousands of atoms, and the slightest disturbance could cause the calculation to come undone.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: But with the principle of quantum factoring proved on paper and now demonstrated in the laboratory, some scientists are optimistic.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: " We have to move far beyond this, " Dr. Chuang said.

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone
sentence: " But at least we have demonstrated that it is possible. "

title: Efforts to Transform Computers Reach Milestone

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE

sentence: LIVING with " Living With Chronic Illness " has turned out to be more of a challenge than I had anticipated.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: After all, I thought as I began to read, having consciously lived with multiple sclerosis for 15 years now, I ' m familiar with the issues the table of contents promises: friendship, for instance, and marriage, parenthood, work, medical care, religious belief.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: What I hadn ' t reckoned on was the effect of spending more than 300 pages confronting all of them once again, not just in myself but in others like me.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: One of my strategies for survival, I realized as I read, is to hold my condition at a little emotional distance - not far enough away so that I can be accused of " denial, " but just far enough so that I acknowledge without fully experiencing its complexities.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: My resistance to " Living With Chronic Illness " marks its strength, I think.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: It pushes the reader squarely up against the pains, the weariness, the uncertainties and, yes, even the rewards of being, as Cheri Register puts it, " interminably ill.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Ms. Register ' s own interminable illness, a rare congenital defect of the liver known as Caroli ' s disease, provides the experimental and emotional ground for the book.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Motivated by the sense of isolation such a rare condition imposes, she began to explore in writing " the ways in which illness had determined the shape of my life.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Then, wisely, she sought out and interviewed others with chronic conditions, among them asthma, diabetes, epilepsy, heart disease, lupus, multiple sclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: As Ms. Register herself recognizes, these 30 sources do not compose a representative sample; thus, special issues of chronic illness among the very poor, the illiterate and homosexuals, for example, remain unexplored.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: But such a limitation is consistent with the conceptual design of the book not as " a controlled social science study " but as " a work for solo and chorus, with my own story at the center, augmented by the voices of others - individual voices, still.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: The result, though intended primarily for the chronically ill, their family and friends, and their doctors, will stir the general reader as well through its intellectual and emotional honesty and meticulous prose.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: I first heard Ms. Register ' s voice years ago in a different setting altogether, an essay reviewing feminist literary criticism that appeared in the prestigious women ' s studies journal Signs.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: I mention this fact not as an interesting aside but because it illustrates a crucial but often overlooked point: as a rule, chronic illness is not a profession.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Ms. Register, for instance, is a writer, lecturer and educational consultant.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: " Though ever-present, " the illness is not even, she observes, " what matters most in people ' s lives.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: On the contrary, chronically ill people engage, often even more earnestly than those who are well, in the range of human experiences valued by society in general: holding responsible jobs and performing them creditably, raising physically and emotionally sturdy children, sustaining close relationships with friends and spouses.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: What distinguishes those with lifelong illnesses is not what they care about or what they do but how they must act: " constructing a life in the spaces between . . . moments of dysfunction, and adopting habits that will keep them to a minimum in intensity and frequency. "

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: A life that unfolds in the interstices of pain and fatigue and outright collapse does differ in significant ways from life in a continuously functional body.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Ms. Register examines those differences, both detrimental and beneficial to human well-being, in enough detail to make them vivid and moving.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: THERE are indeed benefits to enduring chronic illness, Ms. Register makes clear.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: For one thing, " illness makes you appreciate your better moments, and eventually, unless you are constitutionally sour and cynical, you become grateful " for life on its own terms.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: In other words, " lived fully, the experience of illness can free you from the curse of perfectionism that makes happiness conditional on having everything just right. "

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Also, through suffering one learns to share the suffering of others, and " through the gift of compassion, the experience of chronic illness offers protection against apathy, an indifference toward life that means, literally, ' not suffering. '

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Above all, chronic illness leads to the recognition that " somehow, ' things work out ' in a forcibly examined life judged to be worth living. "

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Thus, it frees one from precisely the despair it might be thought, by those who are well, to engender.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: As one of Ms. Register ' s interviewees points out, one can be both sick and happy.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Most texts that try to explore this paradox lapse into inspirational rhetoric, inevitably maudlin and inauthentic.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: Ms. Register quotes one of its characteristic sentiments: " God never gives you more than you can handle " - a patent falsehood, I assure you.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: What rescues this book from the pitfalls of Pollyannaism is Ms. Register ' s scrupulous intelligence and moral vigor.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: " Taking frequent measure of the quality of your life ought to be an obligatory feature of the adjustment to chronic illness, " she writes.

title: REWARDS OF AN INTERRUPTED LIFE
sentence: For all of us, well or chronically ill, " Living With Chronic Illness " provides an admirable guide to this life-enhancing process.

sentence: In " Seasons of Her Life, " Ann Blackman, a veteran reporter for Time, provides a revealing portrait of Albright.

sentence: Blackman, who writes with economy and dispatch, has combed the archives and conducted almost 200 interviews with Albright ' s friends and associates, including President Clinton.

title: Frequent Flier

sentence: A Czechoslovak diplomat, Korbel joined his country ' s government in exile in London after the Nazi takeover.

title: Frequent Flier

sentence: Albright does not seem to have been eager to do so.

sentence: Albright, however, had already encountered some bumps in her life.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: After graduating from Wellesley in 1959, she married the newspaper scion Joseph Albright.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: In 1982, he asked her for a divorce.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: Albright was stunned.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: She started anew teaching at Georgetown University, where she dazzled students with her outgoing personality and blunt speaking style.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: She also devoted much effort to running a salon in her Georgetown home as the Democrats worked to regain the White House.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: She took a decidedly dovish line in the 1980 ' s that she jettisoned with the end of the cold war.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: After working on several political campaigns, including Michael Dukakis ' s ill-fated run for the Presidency, Albright was chosen by President Clinton to become Ambassador to the United Nations.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: Together with her savvy aide, James P. Rubin, currently her press secretary, Albright worked tirelessly to promote herself in the news media.

title: Frequent Flier
sentence: (In her introduction, Blackman says Rubin implied that Albright would cooperate with her in exchange for favorable coverage in Time.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: Despite hints of flexibility by American and Soviet officials, an agreement to reduce long-range arms is not yet within grasp, Administration officials say.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: In a joint announcement today, the United States and the Soviet Union signaled that both sides did not want to settle for an agreement banning only medium- and shorter-range missiles.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: The announcement stressed that the two sides wanted to work toward a more important agreement reducing long-range arms that could be signed during a visit by President Reagan to Moscow in 1988.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: But several difficult hurdles remain.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: Principal among them is a profound disagreement over the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty - a matter that Soviet officials still say must be resolved before a treaty on long-range arms can be completed.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: Differences on Method

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: Even if the two sides could resolve this critical question, there would still be significant differences over how to cut long-range arms.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: On the ABM treaty, the gulf between the two sides still appears wide, though Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the " tone " of the dialogue seemed more positive.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: Under the latest position advanced by Moscow, the Soviet Union insists that each side promise not to withdraw from the ABM treaty for 10 years.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: The United States has offered to observe the treaty through 1994, though some Administration officials have hinted that Washington might be flexible on this count.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: After his meetings with Mr. Shultz and Mr. Reagan, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said this dispute over the period of adherence to the treaty remained.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: A further question is what to do after the pledge not to withdraw from the treaty has expired.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: U.S. Wants ' Star Wars '

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: The United States wants a green light at this point to proceed with the deployment of a space-based missile defense.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: American officials also stress that the two sides would remain bound to the terms of the new treaty reducing long-range arms after adherence to the ABM treaty was dropped.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: But Soviet officials today reportedly repeated their argument that each side should be free to build up their arsenal of long-range arms if the ABM treaty is abandoned.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: The key issue has been how the ABM treaty should be interpreted.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: Last month, Soviet officials said they had proposed that each side adhere to the traditional, strict interpretation of the ABM treaty, which restricts the testing and deployment of anti-missile systems.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: So far, the Reagan Administration has insisted on the right to interpret the treaty broadly so as to allow an expanded pattern of " Star Wars " testing.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: One senior Administration official asserted today that Moscow might be flexible on this issue.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: He asserted that Mikhail S. Gorbachev ' s letter to Mr. Reagan did not repeat earlier Soviet language about strengthening the ABM treaty and stressed the importance of agreeing on a period of non-withdrawal from the treaty.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: Nor does the letter explicitly restate an earlier Soviet proposal that experts meet to clarify what testing is allowed in space, though one official said the letter appeared to allude to this possibility.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: This, he asserted, showed that nailing down a period of non-withdrawal from the treaty was more of a priority for Moscow than securing American agreement to a strict interpretation.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS
sentence: But another senior Administration official disagreed with this interpretation.

title: ACCORD IS ELUSIVE ON STRATEGIC ARMS

title: Personal Health
sentence: ASKING long-married couples why their marriages have endured while nearly half those around them have been torn asunder is like asking 10 blind men to describe an elephant.

title: Personal Health
sentence: The answers vary widely, but nearly always reflect mutual commitment, concern, love and respect.

title: Personal Health
sentence: For most long-married couples, " happily ever after " does not just happen.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Couples in long, happy marriages reflected this fact of life when asked what has made their relationships a success.

title: Personal Health
sentence: " We work to keep the romance alive, " one partner said.

title: Personal Health
Personal Health
sentence: We enjoy our differences and learn from them, " said another.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Still a third said, " We voice our discontents freely and deal with them right away instead of letting them build into thunderclouds. "

title: Personal Health
sentence: But in a way, the thing all the couples have in common was reflected in this observation: " Even when things were really bad, we were both too stubborn to quit.

title: Personal Health
Personal Health
sentence: None of the 10 couples interviewed married with the idea that if things did not work out they could always split.

title: Personal Health
sentence: For many the road to marital longevity was not a smooth one.

title: Personal Health
sentence: The bumps included a very disappointing inability to have children, the death of a child, alcoholism, extramarital affairs, a child with a serious chronic health problem, a difficult economic crisis and highly stressful career changes.

title: Personal Health
sentence: But like a stockholder who invests for the long run, the couples did not consider selling out when the price was down.

title: Personal Health
sentence: And their ability to stick with the marriage through thick and thin paid off, making their relationships stronger and richer.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Although none said so specifically, it was obvious that two other factors were important to their marital success.

title: Personal Health
sentence: First, even though some couples faced considerable differences in personality and sometimes heavy emotional baggage, they maintained respect for one another and refrained from trying to remake their partners.

title: Personal Health
sentence: And second, none of the marriages was marred by psychological disturbances too severe to preclude a true partnership.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Although one or the other may have faltered at times, there were no prolonged periods when either partner was unwilling or unable to contribute to a committed relationship.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Many couples with children are determined to stay together at least until their children are grown.

title: Personal Health
sentence: But couples typically live 20 or 30 years longer, and with just a little effort these years can be among the most fulfilling times in a marriage.

title: Personal Health
sentence: What Therapists Say

title: Personal Health
sentence: Perhaps the best people to ask about the secrets of a successful marriage are the professionals who deal with troubled marriages all the time.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Too often, these therapists find, couples wait until at least one has really decided to call it quits before seeking help, actually looking for confirmation that the marriage cannot work.

title: Personal Health
sentence: These therapists say couples should isolate the trouble spots and make improvements before moving irrevocably toward separation and divorce.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Here are some of their recommendations:

title: Personal Health
sentence: *Work from a position of commitment.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Too many couples believe the secret of a happy marriage is in finding the right mate.

title: Personal Health
sentence: When problems arise, they assume that they made a bad choice and start looking again.

title: Personal Health
sentence: But the real secret is not in finding the right mate but in being the right mate, a mate who is willing to weather the hard times and make the adjustments that come with children, job changes, financial difficulties or simply learning more about the person you married.

title: Personal Health
sentence: *Learn to accept each other ' s shortcomings.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Even happy, well-matched couples can experience conflict, hurt, disappointment and anger.

title: Personal Health
sentence: They may recognize shortcomings in such areas as showing appreciation of each other, willingness to converse and expressing emotions clearly.

title: Personal Health
sentence: But as Dr. Stuart A. Copans, a psychiatrist associated with Dartmouth Medical School, put it, in spite of such difficulties, studies showed that happy couples were able to " maintain a positive attitude toward each other and continue their ability to cooperate, compromise and appreciate each other.

title: Personal Health
sentence: " In an article in the professional magazine Medical Aspects of Human Sexuality, Dr. Copans concluded: " Complaints by themselves don ' t mean that a marriage is unhappy.

title: Personal Health
sentence: It is when those complaints keep the couple from being positive and supportive of each other that the marriage is in trouble. "

title: Personal Health
sentence: *Don ' t shy away from conflict.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Disagreements can lead to marital growth, not distance.

title: Personal Health
sentence: " Conflict is actually a sign of ongoing problem-solving, much as a fever is a symptom of the body ' s battle to overcome illness, " said Marcia Lasswell, a Los Angeles therapist.

title: Personal Health
sentence: But try to appreciate your partner ' s perspective and arrive at a compromise or agree to maintain your differences but respect them.

title: Personal Health
sentence: *When you find yourselves arguing over trivial matters, try to zero in on the real reasons -- for example, the feelings of hurt, fear and neglect -- that underly the anger.

title: Personal Health
sentence: *Do not take understanding for granted.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Too often couples assume that if they really love one another, they will intuitively know what the other wants and needs, inevitably resulting in disappointment.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Problems not dealt with do not go away with time, they simply go underground or loom increasingly larger until a bomb explodes.

title: Personal Health
sentence: *Maintain a balance of power.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Each partner needs to have a sense of personal authority, power, significance and equality.

title: Personal Health
sentence: *Be willing to work at your marriage.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Do not assume that since the first 10 or 20 years were good, the next 10 or 20 will also be good.

title: Personal Health
sentence: Love needs to be fed -- with shared experiences, joys and sorrows.

title: Personal Health
sentence: This requires time, attention and emotional energy.

title: Evidence Supporting Nuclear Tests Is Challenged

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: As Congress confronted a costly railroad labor dispute, the antagonists bitterly disputed whether the shutdown of most of the nation ' s freight railroads was a crisis created by hardline unions or a disruption devised by railroads taking advantage of a decades-old labor law intended to encourage negotiation.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: The debate goes to the heart of labor relations in the railroad industry, for on this issue hinges the rights of rail unions to strike, even in a limited fashion, against an industry that has been increasingly aggressive in cutting its labor costs.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: In three separate sets of contract talks -- one involving machinists and the entire freight rail industry, another with maintenance workers and the freight line Conrail, and the third involving several unions and the passenger line Amtrak -- the unions tried to take the offensive without causing so much disruption that Congress would step in on the industry ' s side.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: But to the unions ' dismay, the rail industry on Wednesday turned a regional machinist strike against one big freight line into a nationwide shutdown.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: Neither Side Pleased

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: That brought Congress reluctantly into the fray, and the solution that Congress put together pleased neither the unions nor the railroads.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: " We are definitely, absolutely, unequivocally opposed to any process that has binding arbitration, " said Mac Fleming, president of the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, which is wrangling over new contracts with Amtrak and the Consolidated Rail Corporation.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: " If the Congress orders us back to work without our basic fundamental right to strike, then Congress is not doing us any favor, " he said.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: The railroads had adamantly urged Congress to put an end to the strike, but not to alter in any way the earlier nonbinding recommendations of mediating boards, which the unions rejected a month ago.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: The railroads had hoped that the nationwide freight shutdown would lead to Congress ' s imposing those terms on the unions.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law
sentence: First the workers must talk directly to their employers.

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

title: Emergency or Ploy?; Railroads Can Turn Sense of Crisis To Advantage Under 1926 Labor Law

sentence: New York: Kodansha International. $21.95.

title: Playing the Japanese Market

title: Playing the Japanese Market

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: , industrial groupings linked together by cross-shareholdings -- are a product of cultural forces peculiar to Japan.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The market is seen not as a forum where Adam Smith ' s invisible hand can work its sometimes rough magic, but something akin to a financial tea ceremony, a cultural institution that reflects the harmonious soul of " Japan Inc. "

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: With careful research and a clear-eyed view of what motivates businessmen, Robert Zielinski and Nigel Holloway, in " Unequal Equities, " go a long way toward shattering that myth.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: In the process, their refreshing look at the ways of corporate Japan demonstrates how the hard rules of finance, rather than the fuzzy virtues of company songs, lifetime employment (available to only a fraction of Japanese workers) or many other famous management techniques, have been key to its competitive prowess.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: As Mr. Zielinski, an American stock analyst in Tokyo, and Mr. Holloway, an English business journalist, make clear, Japanese managers have long regarded finance -- obtaining capital in abundance and as cheaply as possible -- as critically important.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The main difference between them and their American competitors is that they succeeded in shaping their stock market to satisfy their needs while imposing few demands, such as the payment of high dividends.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Indeed Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway present a relatively simple thesis: Big corporations have rigged the Japanese stock market.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The book ' s most provocative pages describe how Japanese managers achieved this.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The story, as Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway tell it, really begins with the American occupation of Japan after World War II.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: One of the key aims was to break up the

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: zaibatsu

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: , the family-controlled holding companies that dominated Japanese industry and had cooperated with the militarists.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The occupation authorities dissolved the holding companies of groups like Mitsubishi and distributed their shares to the public.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: As a consequence, when the Tokyo Stock Exchange reopened in 1949 individuals owned almost 70 percent of the shares.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Companies were forced to pay high dividends, and they were vulnerable to takeover attempts.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Japanese corporations, according to Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway, responded shrewdly.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: They began a campaign to buy themselves up slowly, displacing the individual shareholders.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The companies, moreover, knit themselves into networks by acquiring one another ' s shares.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Today Japanese corporations own 70 percent of the shares listed on the exchange, and Japanese executives demand of one another not a quick buck but what managers most want: growth.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: (On Wall Street, by comparison, individuals or their proxies, mutual funds and pension funds, still own more than half of the publicly traded shares.)

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The result?

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Japanese listed companies pay approximately half the level of dividends that their American competitors pay, retaining capital for new investments.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Shareholders in Japan who want higher payouts simply do not have the power to demand them.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: And, as Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway point out, major Japanese companies are almost immune from unwanted takeovers because friendly shareholders in the form of other companies would never sell to an interloper.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: In addition, it is much easier for Japanese companies to raise capital by selling new securities within these corporate circles.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: American companies slashed their equity by a half trillion dollars in the past decade as they resorted to leveraged buyouts and other such schemes to enrich shareholders.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Japanese companies strengthened themselves by issuing new shares during this period, raising 70 trillion yen, or about $530 billion at current exchange rates.

title: Playing the Japanese Market

title: Playing the Japanese Market

title: Playing the Japanese Market

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Alternatively, Mr. Zielinski and Mr. Holloway show what might happen to an American company like I.B.M. if it were Japanese and did not face shareholder demands for quick returns.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The computer company could save $2.5 billion a year by paying a Japanese-sized dividend and could plow the cash into research and new equipment.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Instead of using its capital to buy back its shares, as it does now to keep the price up, I.B.M. would be raising another $2 billion every year by selling new securities.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: These illustrations can be repetitive, but they make this insightful book readable.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Still, what " Unequal Equities " lacks are the voices of Japan ' s top executives.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: As any journalist in the country knows, getting them on record can be devilishly difficult.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: But it would have added to the book ' s authority had the authors got some Japanese managers to verify the book ' s conclusions, or at least discuss them.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: Another shortcoming of " Unequal Equities " is that it was published before last year ' s stock crash in Japan had run its course.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: The system the authors describe depends on constantly rising share prices.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: So far, however, Japan Inc. does not seem to have missed a beat.

title: Playing the Japanese Market
sentence: In some ways this fact even strengthens the arguments in the book, suggesting that the stock market is a tool, not a reflection, of Japan ' s corporate health.

title: Playing the Japanese Market

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: SCIENTISTS at I.B.M. report that they have overcome a fundamental obstacle to the improvement of microscopes that work using visible light, and that they can now directly examine and analyze fragments of matter as small as genes.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: The device, called a scanning interferometric apertureless microscope, or Siam, can also speedily scan ultracompact optical data storage devices like compact disks.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: Company scientists said the Siam opens the way to making and using memory diskettes the size of pennies, each storing data equivalent to 30 full-length movies.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: The new microscope, invented at the company ' s research center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., is said to be so sharp-eyed that it is potentially capable of determining the spectrums of individual atoms.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: The leader of the group that built it, Dr. Kumar Wickramasinghe, said in an interview that he hoped before the end of the year to obtain the first single-atom spectrums ever recorded.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: Visible light interacts with atoms and molecules to produce characteristic spectrums, patterns that reveal chemical composition.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: Microscope builders for three centuries have been plagued by the fundamental limitation imposed by the wavelength of visible light.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: The user of a traditional light microscope can discern small objects, as long as they are larger than the wavelengths of the light used to view them.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: But smaller objects cannot be " resolved " by conventional microscopes, because the lightwaves are too long to register ultrafine detail.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: However, the wavelengths of atomic particles like electrons are far shorter than the wavelengths of light, and in 1931, this fact was exploited in the electron microscope, which uses an electron beam to make images of ultrasmall objects.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: Since then, the scanning tunneling microscope, also invented by I.B.M. scientists, the atomic force microscope and other devices that do not depend on light have permitted examination of ever smaller objects, including atoms imaged as bumps on highly polished surfaces.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: But these kinds of microscopes do not produce spectrums of the atoms and molecules.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: Now that the Siam microscope can view objects only one-500th the size of the smallest objects that can be seen by conventional light microscopes, Dr. Wickramasinghe said, biologists will be able to identify patterns of genes and other molecules at lightning speed, by pinpointing them with light and identifying the spectral patterns that result from interaction with constituent atoms.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: The Siam device can be attached to conventional light microscopes.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: It uses ordinary lenses to focus laser light to the smallest possible spot on a very thin slice of the sample.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: Under sample ' s is a silicon probe, its tip sharpened by etching to a thickness of one nanometer (one billionth of a meter), about five times the width of one atom.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: The silicon probe, which almost touches the sample, is mounted in a scanning device that vibrates the probe toward and away from the sample 200,000 times a second.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: As it vibrates, the tip scatters some of the light that reaches it after passing through the sample, and another device combines the scattered light with unscattered light to produce an interference pattern revealing the chemical composition of the object.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: With many successive scans, an image of the object is built up.

title: Light Shed on the Tiny
sentence: " This means that biologists will be able to see where antibodies go on the surfaces of antigens, or map genes, or examine the molecular structure of viruses, for example, " Dr. Wickramasinghe said.
