title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: LANGUAGE & SPECIES By Derek Bickerton.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Illustrated. 297 pp.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Chicago: The University of Chicago Press.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: IN 1866 the Linguistic Society of Paris banned all discussion of the origin of human language.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: The ratio of conjecture to evidence had become intolerably high.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: More than a century later, it remains unclear when and how the capacity for language arose.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Even Derek Bickerton, who has chosen to write a book on the subject, admits that all we know for sure is that language " emerged somewhere between the separation of the hominid line from other primates and the dawn of recorded history.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: He also admits, a bit defensively, that parts of his analysis are therefore " speculative in the extreme. "

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Yes, they are.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: But no apology is needed.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Mr. Bickerton, a linguist at the University of Hawaii, has illuminated this elusive subject with an assortment of circumstantial evidence, ingeniously employed.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: The result is a book that, whatever the eventual fate of its central arguments, is bound to prove fertile.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: In Mr. Bickerton ' s much-discussed 1981 book, " Roots of Language, " he argued that humans are born with a " bioprogram, " a specific grammatical model that each child amends, through trial and error, to match the peculiarities of the native tongue.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: This theory is one variant of the widely accepted notion that some genetically based machinery guides language acquisition, especially during the crucial phase between ages 2 and 4, when babies turn from expert babblers into novice talkers.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: But how was this machinery built?

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: In " Language & Species, " Mr. Bickerton dismisses the simplest answer -- that our linguistic skills evolved seamlessly from those of apes.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: True, gorillas and chimpanzees can be taught to associate arbitrary signs -- hand gestures or keyboard symbols -- with concepts, such as " banana " or " eat, " and to string these signs together meaningfully.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: But there remains a chasm between our language and theirs, Mr. Bickerton says.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: For example, there is no evidence that apes can make much use of certain grammatical elements (articles, prepositions, auxiliary verbs and so on).

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Nor do they benefit from syntactical rules, which permit the flexible construction of complex yet unambiguous utterances, complete with subordinate clauses and other structural subtleties.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Consider this statement from Nim Chimpsky, the chimp named after the linguist Noam Chomsky: " give orange me give eat orange me eat orange give me eat orange give me you. "

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Yes, we get the message.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Still.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Mr. Bickerton calls this ape language " proto language. "

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: What is interesting is that he finds proto language (sometimes in a slightly more advanced form) spoken by a variety of humans as well: by children before the age of 2; by a woman whose deranged father kept her in solitary confinement until the age of 13, and who, though generally intelligent, was forever frozen in her linguistic development ( " Paint. Paint picture. Take home " ; " Applesauce buy store " ); and by slaves from different cultures who, once thrown together, improvise a crude system of communication, a pidgin language.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Notably, the slaves ' children, who are exposed to the pidgin vocabulary before the age of 2, expand the protolanguage into a structurally mature language called a creole.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: And the grammatical rules that emerge, says Mr. Bickerton, are remarkably constant from one creole language to the next.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: (This fact figured centrally in his hypothesis that every child is born with a bioprogram for language.)

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: All of this suggests to Mr. Bickerton that the cerebral machinery for protolanguage is quite distinct from the additional machinery needed for true human language, and that this additional machinery is activated -- and can only be activated -- during the 2-to-4-year-old phase.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Mr. Bickerton suspects that natural selection began to enhance the protolanguage machinery more than a million years ago, as our ancestors roamed the savanna in search of food, presumably dividing into small groups for foraging.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Those who could communicate were better able to organize their expeditions and report their finds.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Ultimately, though, it wasn ' t the communicative function of language that played the crucial evolutionary role, according to Mr. Bickerton.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Rather, it was language ' s contribution to thought, its value as " a system of representation, " as a tool for sorting information and drawing inferences, that aided human survival and reproduction.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: This representational aspect of language further enhanced the protolanguage machinery and finally fueled the jump to true language.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Mr. Bickerton believes this socially momentous leap was biologically small.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Once the elements of advanced protolanguage, including basic grammatical items, were in place, the crucial addition, syntax, was fairly simple.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: It took the form of an uncomplicated cerebral " governor " in charge of determining how the grammatical elements could and couldn ' t be neurologically interconnected.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Mr. Bickerton thinks that the capacity for syntax emerged with modern Homo sapiens more than 100,000 years ago, and he sees it as responsible for the cognitive revolution reflected in the florescence around 40,000 years ago of bladed tools, stone figurines, cave paintings and lunar calendars.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: THIS book has no shortage of ideas with which to take issue.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Biologists may have trouble swallowing (among other things) Mr. Bickerton ' s suggestion that the brain ' s entire syntactical apparatus, as well as the modern, articulate vocal tract, resulted from a single genetic mutation.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: And his final two chapters will draw fire from various quarters -- partly for their sheer audacity (they are called " Mind, Consciousness, and Knowledge " and " The Nature of the Species " ), partly for their texture (Mr. Bickerton ' s exposition, which in general is precise yet demandingly fast-paced, here becomes nearly breathless) and partly for a deeper reason: there is cause to question the analytical utility -- though perhaps not the technical accuracy -- of Mr. Bickerton ' s uncompromising emphasis on language as the maker of the human predicament, the source of evils ranging from war to social inequality.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Yet, even as you resist Mr. Bickerton ' s sometimes radical ideas, you are drawn into his appreciation of the dominant role language plays not only in what we say, but in what we think and, therefore, what we are.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: Though there is something grandiose about titling a book " Language & Species " (especially with no subtitle!), there is something grand about Mr. Bickerton ' s world view.

title: We Talk; Therefore We Think
sentence: And though his speculations may (and, of course, may not) turn out to have outrun his evidence, they are certainly worth pursuing.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: It ' s the architecture of the large and expensive new buildings -- the glass-roofed museums, the granite-faced office towers, the glamorous hotels -- that catches the media ' s, and the public ' s, attention.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: But all the institutional, commercial and industrial buildings put together account for less than half the money spent on new buildings every year.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: The rest is spent on a single category: residential construction.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: And more than two-thirds of this category consists of a building type that ' s so ordinary it ' s almost invisible -- the single-family house.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: About one million new single-family houses are built annually across the country, the vast majority by merchant builders.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Though there are currently about 120,000 individual builders in the United States, American housing is marked by uniformity rather than diversity.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: This fact was recently brought home to me when I took part in judging the 1991 Builder ' s Choice Design and Planning Awards, an annual event organized by Builder, the leading magazine of the American home-building industry; in reviewing several hundred submissions, I was struck by the frequency with which similar designs cropped up.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: The homogeneity of American housing is due in part to similar building codes and standardized technology, and in part to the mobility of consumers, but it ' s also the result of an industry that is increasingly driven by trends and fashions -- what merchandisers call pushing the hot buttons.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: What were the hot buttons this year?

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Huge, well-appointed master bedrooms, for one.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Even without counting the now obligatory private bathroom, dressing room, and his and hers walk-in closets, the master bedroom has become easily the largest room in the house, taking up most of the second floor and often including such features as balconies, fireplaces and skylights.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: The modern master bedroom recalls the vast bedchambers of pre-Revolutionary France, in which the aristocratic bedroom was often used for social as well as private functions.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: It makes one wonder if the custom of the morning levee is about to return.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: The expansion of the master bedroom is often at the cost of the living room, which has shrunk, and in many houses resembles a sort of waiting room, with just enough space for a sofa and a couple of chairs.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Instead of the living room, it ' s the so-called great room that now takes center stage.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Despite its medieval-sounding name, the great room combines the roles of the Georgian library, the Victorian drawing room and the 1950 ' s rec room; it marks another step in the evolution of the family room that began with the basement playroom, which was really an improvised location for the television set.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Although the architectural style of new housing remains firmly traditional (Spanish colonial and Mediterranean in the west and southwest, American colonial in the northeast), the interior arrangement of most houses has been affected by the modernistic notion of the open plan.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Consequently, the living room, dining room, kitchen and great room are conceived as part of one single, unobstructed, flowing space.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: This provides visual excitement as well as a feeling of roominess (American home buyers apparently love wide open spaces), but it does create difficulties with noise.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: Whatever the style of the exterior architecture, one rule appears to hold true: the facade along the street must be sprinkled with bay windows, recesses, protrusions, overhangs and uneven roof-lines.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too
sentence: This architectural articulation provides the maximum of what builders call curb appeal.

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: A House Is a Home, but It's Something Else, Too

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: " The Wilds and the Deep, " the latest collaboration between Martha Fleming and Lyne Lapointe, is something of a disappointment.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: The duo ' s installation " Eat Me/Drink Me/Love Me, " which was on view last winter at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in SoHo, marked a departure for the Montreal-based artists, who prefer as venues unused or dilapidated buildings, places that evoke their works ' recurrent themes of abandonment and isolation.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Ms. Lapointe and Ms. Fleming redesign parts of such buildings, creating site-specific installations and occasionally staging performances in them.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: With " The Wilds and the Deep, " they have altered one of the abandoned boat slips of the hulking Battery Maritime Building, hanging objects like a bell and a canoe on chains, placing masks, grasses and skulls atop the slip ' s pilings, painting an image of a bishop ' s miter on a suspended bridge, constructing a kind of grotto and, at the edge of the pier, cobbling together with wood and string what looks like a dinosaur ' s skeleton.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: On the second floor they have, among other things, installed a cabinet of artifacts, hung a chandelier with a fleur-de-lis pattern evocative of the artists ' Quebec roots, painted the floor with a map of the Americas, strung beaver skins across the rafters and exhibited a folding screen that depicts motifs, like the dinosaur and the beaver, that are to be found throughout the installation.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Finally, on the roof, so that it can be seen clearly from several nearby corporate office towers, they have laid out a canvas on which is painted rows of black figures representing the slaves who passed through this port in the 19th century.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Colonialism, attitudes toward women on the part of the Roman Catholic Church and the pillage of nature are among the eclectic subjects that " The Wilds and the Deep " means to address.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: In particular, the port seems to serve for Ms. Fleming and Ms. Lapointe as an symbol of the colonization of the Americas by Europeans.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: The references to dinosaurs and beavers, for instance, are evidently reminders of the continent ' s prehistory and of the attack on wildlife by the settlers and their descendants.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: The cabinet of artifacts is intended to evoke the despoiling of native cultures by the Europeans, who then stocked their museums with their booty.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: The relationship between colonialism and the development of botany and the museum is central to " The Wilds and the Deep. "

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: None of this, however, offers itself up to the viewer easily.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: And in this sense, the work of Ms. Lapointe and Ms. Fleming can be compared to installations by Ronald Jones.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: It is the strength and weakness of this sort of densely textual art that points are made in a fragmentary and, very often, obscure way.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: The strength in the case of " The Wilds and the Deep " is that a viewer comes unexpectedly on the more discreet parts of the installation, particularly those around the boat slip, and, in trying to distinguish between the original building and what has been added to it, enters into the process of deciphering that is fundamental to Ms. Lapointe and Ms. Fleming ' s ideology.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: For these artists, there is always a subtext to be uncovered.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: But in the case of " The Wilds and the Deep, " competing subtexts create what is not so much complexity as confusion and dispersal, a kind of laundry list of griefs.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: And it should be said that although " The Wilds and the Deep " is in part a critique of the way objects wrenched from their native cultures or environments are venerated, the installation is full of precious details that tempt a viewer to make fetishes of Ms. Lapointe and Ms. Fleming ' s alterations and constructions.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: " The Wilds and the Deep, " an installation by Martha Fleming and Lyne Lapointe, remains on view at the Battery Maritime Building, Whitehall Street, next to the Staten Island Ferry Terminal, Thursdays to Sundays, noon to 6 P.M., through June 24.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: These dozen or so recent works by the British sculptor David Nash are beautifully carved and richly evocative meditations on the relationship between nature and culture.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: They are made from trees that are already cut down or diseased, in which Mr. Nash discovers shapes like giant spoons, mushrooms, stacks of papers, mosaic eggs and boats.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Each piece is constructed from a single tree, and it is among the artist ' s talents to disguise this fact by varying textures and executing feats of carving so that the effect in works like " Red Throne, " " Crack and Warp Column " or " Six Birch Spoons " is of many different segments put together.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: These, however, are not sculptures about virtuosity.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: For all the skill that went into the making of the works, Mr. Nash achieves an impression of simplicity and straightforwardness that recalls down-home craftsmanship.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: As did Scott Burton, he elevates everyday forms and utilitarian objects to the level of art not only by working on a monumental scale, but also by evoking a process of ritual.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Works like " Comet Ball, " " Vessel and Volume " and " Black Stack Threshold Column " have been burned, as if in some kind of ceremony.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: The ceremony, in Mr. Nash ' s case, would seem to be about metamorphosis and about the preservation of nature in the manmade environment.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: This exhibition of 40 works does not dispel the impression that Niles Spencer (1893-1952) was a follower of Precisionists like Charles Sheeler and that his work, for the most part, lacks the crispness and bite to be found in Sheeler ' s best paintings and photographs.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Spencer studied in 1916 with Robert Henri at the Francisco Ferrer School in the Bronx, and he became especially influenced by the work of Paul Cezanne, an influence that can easily be discerned in a painting like " Trees and Farmhouse, Southern France, " which the artist completed during one of his trips to Europe in the early 1920 ' s.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: From that time on, Spencer ' s career moved toward an abstraction based on architectural forms.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Painting scenes of New York City; western Pennsylvania; Provincetown, Mass.; Ogunquit, Me., and Bristol, R.I., he developed a highly economical style of flat, simplified forms and subtle shifts of tone.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: By the late 1940 ' s, with " The Silver Tanks " (1949) and then with " Above the Excavation " (1950), Spencer was at his most abstract, transforming buildings into jaunty designs that can bring to mind the paintings of Stuart Davis.

title: Review/Art;   Varieties of Colonialism In Dockside Installation
sentence: Somewhat surprisingly, the exhibition makes its strongest case for Spencer ' s appeal with a group of still lifes, including " Studio Table " of 1925 and " The Green Table " of 1930, both of which exude a warmth and richness of detail eschewed by the artist in the landscapes and cityscapes on which he concentrated most of his energies.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: In the meantime, however, the New Jersey renaissance (as the public relations people like to call it) isn ' t generating too much derogatory humor these days, and for an ex-Jerseyan like me, this fact provokes some profoundly mixed feelings.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: After all, my sensibilities were shaped by those signs on Main Street that marked the George Washington Retreat Route, reminding me throughout my childhood that I lived in a place that Washington had not slept in but rather had fled.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: Throughout most of the 1970 ' s, in fact, most of my friends and I suffered from a once common New Jersey malady, something we called the Canada Syndrome, roughly defined as an overwhelming sensation of being right next door to where all the action is.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: To trapped Jerseyans like us, life was elsewhere - in Manhattan, to be exact, just a few short miles across the Hudson River.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: We used to stand on the Palisades cliffs and watch the city gleaming mountainously on the horizon, pulsing with life, promising whatever it was that New Jersey didn ' t have.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: Of course, what Jersey " did " have - garbage dumps, Cadillacs and discount stores the size of Carnegie Hall - we regarded as the epitome of the suburban cliche, something to escape from at the earliest possible moment.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: Eventually, some of us managed to emulate Washington and flee Fort Lee, though in the opposite direction, over the bridge that bears his name.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: In New York we sought the meaningful lives that were clearly incompatible with backyard barbecues and plaster figurines of deer and gnomes on the front lawn.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: Some of us became actors, writers, graphic artists and (most glamorous of all) investment bankers.

sentence: We began eating in restaurants that served baby eggplants and hard-to-pronounce varieties of fish baked in parchment.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: God forgive us, we became New York hip.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: Imagine our confusion, then, when we began to hear the first rumblings of the New Jersey renaissance.

sentence: It all started when Jersey City and Hoboken became fashionable neighborhoods for artists (Hoboken! My father was born in Hoboken!).

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: And nowadays economics seems to be following art across the Hudson.

sentence: We see newspaper advertisements in which Mayor Edward I. Koch boards up the Lincoln Tunnel to prevent businesses from fleeing " to, " not " from, " New Jersey.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: We hear about a new technology belt running the length of the tacky highway I used to travel to go to college.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: There are even polls now that show 84 percent of Jerseyites rating the state as a good or excellent place to live.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: These developments have sparked something of a crisis among us Jersey expatriates.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: We ' re falling prey to a growing suspicion that our quality of life is not inversely proportional to our distance from St. Mark ' s Place.

sentence: Many of us, especialy those who are contemplating a move from the city for reasons of biological reproduction, are even beginning to think the unthinkable: We ' re starting to browse - just browse, mind you - the New Jersey pages in the Sunday real estate ads.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: The irony, of course, is that everything in our old hometown is now far beyond our means.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: Everyone tells us that we should have been looking five years ago.

sentence: That ' s the curse of our generation of end-of-the-baby-boom-ers; we ' re five years too late for everything.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: But in certain towns a little farther out, something affordable and small, a handyman special perhaps. . . .

sentence: The New Jersey renaissance is reclaiming its own.

title: The Once And Future Jerseyans
sentence: And our mothers are just thrilled.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: SINCE 1977, Bishop William E. Lori has served in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Washington where he assisted Cardinal James A. Hickey for 18 years before the cardinal retired in December.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Now, the 49-year-old Bishop Lori will succeed another cardinal, the former archbishop of the Diocese of Bridgeport, Edward M. Egan, who was named archbishop of New York last June and was recently installed as a cardinal in a ceremony in Rome.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Bishop Lori, who will be installed in his new post tomorrow in a by-invitation-only ceremony at 2 p.m. in the William H. Pitt Center at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, had never even been to Bridgeport until a few months ago, after he was surprised to learn of his new assignment.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: In his new role Bishop Lori will be the fourth spiritual leader of the Bridgeport Diocese since it was established in 1953.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: The diocese, which now serves 360,000 Catholics throughout Fairfield County, includes 88 parishes, 33 regional elementary schools, 5 high schools and 25 program offices of Catholic Charities that provide the largest private network of social services in southwestern Connecticut.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Bishop Lori, who decided he wanted to become a priest while growing up in Louisville, Ky., is soft spoken, but has strong beliefs about the importance of maintaining traditional church doctrine.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: He is no stranger to controversy, having handled a case while in Washington involving four Maryland priests charged with sexual abuse in 1995.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: The priests eventually confessed to the abuse and were dismissed, and Bishop Lori was praised for handling the case with rare openness.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Recently, Bishop Lori, who was ordained a priest in 1977 and named auxiliary bishop in Washington in 1995, spoke of his experiences in the nation ' s capital and of his impending installation in Bridgeport.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Following are excepts from that conversation at the Catholic Center in the main offices of the Diocese of Bridgeport.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Q.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: As the new bishop of the Diocese of Bridgeport, what is your first priority?

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: A.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: I think the first thing a bishop has to do when he comes into a diocese is to make sure not to super-impose a program from somewhere else on a new place.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: The first need that people have is for me to go out into the parishes, and for me to get to know them, to listen to them and develop a truly accurate and profound understanding of the strengths, needs and resources here.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Q.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Fairfield County is one of the most affluent counties in the country, and yet its largest city, Bridgeport, is an urban center beset by problems of poverty, crime, homelessness, drug addiction and teen pregnancy.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: How do you juggle the needs of two vastly different communities within the diocese?

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: A.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: I ' m used to that because Washington is a similar community in that way.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: We have tremendous poverty in the inner city, we have schools that are failing, health care that is breaking down in the city, and even though the city is revitalizing itself -- as Bridgeport is striving to do -- the needs are tremendous.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: At the same time, in Washington, as here, there is wealth and a lot of middle class persons as well.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Q. What are your thoughts of succeeding Cardinal Egan, who has become an icon in this area now that he has moved on to New York and whom you have stated possesses talents and abilities that you do not?

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: A. Cardinal Egan did a wonderful job here and I hope we will benefit for years to come from what he contributed.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: At the same time, I believe that when you come to a place you have to be your own person and the person that God made you to be.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: So I bring a different mix of talents, a different personality.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: Q. A lot has changed within society since you began to pursue your dream of becoming a priest.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: I think the church has to be herself.

sentence: The church that totally succumbs to the times is a church that is going to go out of existence.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: There are times when the church has got to be a sign of contradiction.

title: Q & A/Bishop William E. Lori; 'A Different Mix of Talents, A Different Personality'
sentence: The truth has got to be the defender of human life, even when that is socially, culturally and legally unpopular.

sentence: Q.

title: Judges, Nominations and Roe v. Wade

sentence: I don ' t have a litmus test.

sentence: There is not one single issue that would make me vote for or against a judge.

sentence: The bottom line is very simple.

sentence: My standard, which is the standard I think the founding fathers wanted, is that judges should interpret the law, not make the law.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: A CLASS of fats that is widespread in the American diet has been linked to an increased risk of developing breast cancer.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: The substances, called trans fatty acids, are prominent in many processed and fast foods, margarines and some vegetable oils.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: A study of nearly 700 postmenopausal European women found that those whose bodies contained the highest levels of trans fatty acids were 40 percent more likely than those with the lowest levels to develop breast cancer.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: The greatest risk -- three and a half times as high as the risk among those with the lowest levels -- was seen among women with both the highest trans fatty acid levels and low levels of polyunsaturated fatty acids.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: The lead researcher on the study, Dr. Lenore Kohlmeier, professor of epidemiology and nutrition at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, said the findings might be especially relevant to American women, whose intake of trans fatty acids is about twice that of European women.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: The new study, published last month in the journal Cancer Epidemiology, is believed to be more accurate than most because it measured the fatty acid content of the women ' s body fat rather than asking them about the foods they ate.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: The researchers analyzed tiny fat samples taken from the buttocks, which provide the truest reflection of dietary intake of various kinds of fats.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: Trans fatty acids do not occur naturally in food.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: They are formed when vegetable oils are partly hydrogenated to form margarine and other solid vegetable cooking fats.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: Trans fatty acids are also added to some liquid vegetable oils to extend their shelf life, although this fact is not stated on the label.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: Previous studies have linked trans fatty acids to an increased risk of heart disease.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: Dr. Kohlmeier said that people can reduce their intake and body burden of trans fatty acids by changing their diets.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: She said that it would take about two years for a reduced intake of these fats to be reflected as a lower level in stored body fat.

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
sentence: The researcher is currently following a large group of women who have had breast cancer to determine whether the level of trans fatty acids in their bodies affects their risk of a recurrence.
